author: Katie Dickinson
title: North East MEPs go head to head in EU referendum debate - Chronicle Live
text:
North East MEPs go head to head in EU referendum debate 10:11, 5 Jun 2016 Jonathan Arnott and Jude Kirton-Darling argued for and against Brexit at a debate in Hexham Shares Get daily news by email From left: Guy Opperman MP, chair George Hepburn, Jude Kirton-Darling MEP and Andy Saunders 
North East MEPs went head to head in a debate on whether Britain should leave or stay in the European Union . 
The event at Queen Elizabeth High School, in Hexham , saw politicians from the Leave and Remain camps being grilled by locals. 
North East Labour MEP Jude Kirton-Darling and Hexham MP Guy Opperman were stating the case to remain, while UKIP MEP Jonathan Arnott and Britain for Business representative Andy Saunders argued for Brexit. 
Ms Kirton-Darling said import tariffs would “kill” the automotive industry in the North East of Britain voted to leave. 
She said: “80% of the cars made at Sunderland go to the European market and World Trade Organisation tariffs would kill the industry which supports tens of thousands of jobs in the North East, not just in manufacturing but in services,” she said. 
“As a country we are a service economy and we would be killing ourselves by applying WTO rules.” 
The MEP also argued that the EU was “completely democratic”. 
She added: “We can rewrite proposals and we can reject proposals we don’t want. 
“If you wanted you could watch European Parliament all day long – it’s the lack of interest from the British media which means it is not properly presented in the way Westminster is. 
“At the moment we are leading in Europe and our European partners are desperate for us to continue doing that.” 
The EU referendum debate at Queen Elizabeth High School, Hexham 
But fellow North East MEP Mr Arnott insisted the UK had “a 100% record of failure” in trying to change EU laws. 
He said: “British MEPs don’t vote as a block, and therefore it’s difficult for them to stop something in the European Parliament. 
“We have only opposed 72 things and every single one of those has gone on to become law anyway.” 
Mr Arnott added: “Sovereignty and security are intrinsically linked and we have seen the EU erode our sovereignty. 
“There are so many things we could do outside the EU, such as stop the over-fishing of our waters and regain control of our fishing industry.” 
During the debate the panel faced questions from audience members about democracy in Europe, the future of the Eurozone, and the role of the EU in international relations. 
On the subject of diplomacy, Mr Opperman said: “We need to think about how we are going to cope with our problems in the future. 
“History shows us that if we isolate ourselves and build barriers, things get worse.” 
When asked about immigration Andy Saunders, of Britain for Business, said: “I’m quite ashamed of Britain over what we are doing with Syrian refugees – if we control immigration it may well be we can take in more people from refugee camps. 
“If companies can’t find workers with the skills they need, it will encourage them to get involved with local colleges and schools and train them to do the jobs that are needed, rather than bringing in labour from abroad.”
